bibl.title: Gin Kato v. State of Washington
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: This alien was arrested on the charge that he was found employed by, in, or in connection with a house of prostitution.

He admits having been employed as a cook in a house of the character noted, for a period of seven months. He claims to have been resident in the United States since 1884, being for sometime employed on ships, and later residing in Alaska. He has a wife in Japan. The attorney contends that prostitutes in the restricted districts of Ketchikan were allowed to have Chinese or Japanese cooks because aliens of these nationalities were less likely to cause disturbance than others, and makes a plea for leniency. The charge is clearly sustained, and there appears no reason to believe that deportation would be an unusual hardship.
